hotspots.hotspot:
Granite

Granite contains grains that are large enough to see even without a magnifying lens. Granite has many uses. Some kitchen countertops, paving stones, and monuments are made of granite. Walls built for rock-climbers can also be made of granite.

Basalt

Basalt is a fine-grained rock that is used in construction. Basalt is also used as lava rocks for grills and ovens. The ancient Romans used basalt to build the seats in their stadiums such as the Colosseum.

hotspots.hotspot:
Metamorphic Rock

The term metamorphic rock comes from the Greeks words meta, which means "changed" and morphos, which means "shape."

Slate

This is slate. Slate is an example of a metamorphic rock. Slate is used as tiles for both floors and roofs.

Marble

Another familiar metamorphic rock is marble, which is used in sculptures, buildings, and monuments such as the George Washington monument in Washington, D.C.

hotspots.hotspot:
Sedimentary Rocks

Under heat and pressure, sedimentary rock turns into metamorphic rock.

Igneous Rocks

Under heat and pressure, igneous rock turns into metamorphic rock. However, weathering and erosion help to transform igneous rock into sedimentary rock.

Metamorphic Rocks

Weathering and erosion help to transform metamorphic rock into sedimentary rock.

Magma

When sedimentary and metamorphic rocks melt, they form magma. When magma cools, it forms igneous rock.
